author: LactobaSILLY
body:
No, it’s nearly at 52 week highs. Yeah the breakout stock in a recession/depression with extreme unemployment is a solar company that has high costs to convert struggling businesses/homeowners from fossil fuel dependency to solar dependency. Maybe if things were going really well for businesses and consumers, this would. And it probably will be in the future. But to say with 30% or whatever of citizens out of work and majority of businesses showing decreased revenue and earnings, now is clearly not the time to pay a big up front fee to convert when they’re worried about paying employees and leases next month. Long shares, sure. Calls a month out? Fuck no. Maybe leaps. **maybe**. Even jpow said this shit economy will take longer than originally expected to bounce back. Enph is cyclical, it drives up then drives down. I would be weary and trying to find a peak to sell your shares and I goddamn sure wouldn’t be buying a call.

Also as another comment posted, your claim of 97.5% efficiency from solar panels is only attainable if you have some fucking alien technology, they all sit around 20% and MAX 45%. Ain’t no fucking business or consumer paying 10,000% premium to squeeze an extra 20% off efficiency when I can connect to city power for 1/25 of the upfront cost and even if I did, I wouldn’t expect to see a recoup of my initial upfront investment of “going green” for 5 years. Plus, virus.

author: sc_shay20
body:
If I have capital available to deploy to DCA one of my holdings at a price point below my cost-basis, I absolutely will. At a certain point, I would stop though as I do not want to become too overweight one position. I view doing this as a sale, as long as my conviction about the company hasn’t deterred. 

They are similar companies, but operate in different niches. I don’t think they are necessarily “competitors” as they do different things, but they are both the leaders in the industry. 

ENPH is a pretty great company, with great growth prospects. Although, ENPH is definitely trading at more of a premium in comparison right now, due to crushing its most recent earnings and providing solid outlook. 

ENPH’s business model is not as capital intensive as you might think, as during 2020Q1 they reported their highest GP margin ever, and their TTM profit margin is higher than SEDGs (31.2% to 10.7%). 

I think I might open a position in SEDG within the next week, as I think it’s at pretty fair value right now. Especially when comparing to ENPH.

author: chromegreen
body:
Solar cell manufacturing is very competitive and low margin as competitors continue to try to price each out of markets.

Alternative energy companies with income generating infrastructure or proprietary technology are more likely to succeed.

ENPH and SEDG provide power converters and related services to get solar power onto the AC power grid.

AY and NEP operate solar and wind infrastructure along with things like desalination plants and natural gas infrastructure.

HASI is structured as a REIT and has a diverse portfolio including implementation of energy conservation and efficiency technology.

BEP focuses on hydropower but holds some other alternative energy solutions

CVA is an energy from waste service provider.

GPP manages corn ethanol infrastructure.

EVA focuses on power generation from wood products.

ORA is the leading geothermal energy provider.

Some of these, like ENPH, may be overpriced right now due to speculation about future success.  But others are at lows due to a drop in energy demand from the pandemic. 

Some these are structured as MLPs which adds some tax paperwork although I think BEP has a non-MLP option now.

author: patriot2024
body:
The present giants are not the same as dinosaurs of the past.  They learned the goods and the bads from giants of yesterday.

IBM is a dinosaur. It became a dinosaur with the emergence of personal computers. But while many dinosaurs have been dead for years, IBM is still alive because -- IMO -- it has done one thing right: IBM Research.   IBM Research is what has kept IBM alive, staying with the youngsters.  

Guess what. The current giants have learned from this. They all have invested heavily in research.  Most interestingly is Google. Most of their products are "betas", which are experimental research projects that are deployed to the public.

Another thing the giants have learned is that they need to be very flexible and adaptive to rising trends.   Microsoft raised because of the dominant of software, which by the way was the dead sentence for hardware giants.   But this dominant almost killed Microsoft, turning it into a dinosaur, when software became a commodity and not a specialty product.  Demanding customers to pay for each version of Windows and Word was no longer the right thing to do, Microsoft adapted to a model the sells software as a service.  And they have survived. They have also excelled due to Microsoft Research. This has allowed them to stay at the forefront.

Google, Apple and FaceBook will be the dominating players in the near future because -- IMO -- data, data about people, and the interconnection of people have become more important than anything else.

It is very possible that data will become cheap in some sense, a commodity.  Although data has become more open, certain types of data can be very expensive to collect.  So I think Google and FaceBook will continue to have a promising future.

Apple is in a very interesting situation. It doesn't sell a product.   Other cellphone companies sell utilities. But Apple sells the experience of people connecting to people. It's like FaceBook in some way.  People inherent want to connect to other people. This is a lasting value. As long as Apple excels at this, it will be around for a long time.

author: jonhuang
body:
Well, the incremental value of data might decline. Lots of big companies are built on technological change but no change lasts forever. Car companies for example. Or oil/coal--OPEC probably seemed invincible but between demand drops, renewables and fracking they no longer seem as invincible as before. Or moore's law powered companies like IBM, Dell, Microsoft but is now slowing down (in both tech and demand for faster personal computers). 

So is it inconceivable that data mining might top out too? Legislation, or using anonymous VPNs become like brushing your teeth, or  every company has so much data that it levels out. Google knows when I flip lightswitches in my house but it's not as valuable as reading my email and exact location, surely.

> they ain't going away

It doesn't mean they won't lose value. IBM hasn't gone away but it lost its dominance and sharehodlers haven't reaped the same profits in the past decades as they did in its heyday. It could be worse: Kodak and Nokia are still around too!

Too often people in this sub think "can't disappear = can't lose money" but it couldn't further from the truth. There are many ways a business can destroy shareholder value, or simply underperform the market, without going bankrupt.

author: BarbarX3
body:
I don't have an opionion on many of these, but I have looked into some. What I am missing most about your list is the financials and management analysis. Good investments are only good if you can calculate an expected return on the capital, otherwise you're just hoping that the stock goes up in value because someone else will be there to pay even more than you did without any underlying reason. Good investments are only good if it is managed so that shareholders get their returns. For lots of companies the shareholder is just another customer that they can get money from to run their business, whatch out for that.

I have some opinions(!) on the following:

\- FB: They rely solely on their scale and networkeffect to make money. I don't see a moat that protects that network. New exciting apps can greatly reduce this networkeffect, and their scale and profitability with it. With that in mind I can not say definitvely that they will be around in 5, 10, 20 or 30 years. THey might be, they might not be. But if I can not be 100% certain the comapny will be around for the next 30 years, I'm not putting my money in it (rule nr 1: don't loose money). I also don't like the management, they don't seem honest to their users, customers or shareholders.

\- MSFT: This is one of my biggest holdings. I think the company is run well, the financials are in order, their markets are increasing, many businesses depend on them and are locked in (which is only getting stronger). I don't see them disappearing anytime soon, and even if they have bad years they can scale down in costs, and have enough time and capital to try new things. The only thing I'm worried about at the moment is their popularity, you may be buying at a high price now because there aren't as many good alternatives. I try to avoid popularity like that (what happens to the hot 20yr old when she turns 40?).

\- WM: I think they are now popular/hype without any good reason. The company might be solid, but I think their growth is not gonna be spectactular. Half the current price would be more realistic if you plan to hold forever.

\- Cisco: Old behemoth like IBM. They might do well, good long term outlook and their price is acceptable. For the next 30 years they will need to keep up with new technologies and I have a nagging feeling they are milking their existing customers and not focusing on the future enough. Not in my portfolio, but well worth considering.

\- Apple: I own a couple shares. Great lock-in, good rpicing power, good consumer satisfaction, but future may still be uncertain looking forward 30 years. They depend on constant innovation and trying to get people that next "fix" as it were. I'm not sure they can keep that up for years and years and years. Current price is high but acceptable I think, but be on the lookout for changing consumer behavior (new more exciting companies can nibble at their marketshare).

\- TMobile: I think telecoms are going to face some serious headwinds as satellite cell network communications start. That will be some years from now, but systems like starlink might become serious global contendors wiping out current investments by telco's. I'm not sure investment made now will give you the return you need long term. My money is on starlink IPO.

\- Financials: I stick to european and canadian banks. Not really any reason other then I don't have first hand experience with american banks.

\- Volkswagen: I think the car market is too competitive to ever give a steady return without risk of being wiped out multiple times in between. No carmaker has any moat over others. I don't think Tesla has a moat, I don't think Volkwagen has either. If I look for a new car, I don't have any brand loyalty. Their is no real reason for me to buy a volkswagen over a toyato, kia or renault. I think Tesla is massively overvalued, I bought the model3 but returned it in the first week because of all kinds of quality and service problems. I like my 10yr old volvo better. Therefor I don't see any reason to invest in any of them.

\- Panasonic: I agree with your assesment. I own some shares myself. The company is well run and well positioned to take advantage of a growing market. It may not be a quick return, but I believe long term they will do well.

\- Crypto: It doesn't produce anything of value nor is it a resource that can be used in production. It is not regulated or controlled by any meaningfull organisation. It is highly manipulated and riddled with fraud (my opinion). Therefor I don't see why it has any inherent value, and I don't own any nor ever have or will. Would you buy land that doesn't produce anything and you cannot build on? Gold has it's uses, just like silver and other scarce metals. Crypto has no inherent use, I would even argue that it's consuming energy to create nothing, and should therefor be of negative value.

author: msnf
body: IBM isn't much of a nightmare scenario for big tech, considering how long it held its value after losing its technical advantages. If you had bought IBM stock at the height of the early 2000's dot-com bubble, you would've been ahead of the market until [as late as 2017](https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/IBM/chart?p=IBM#%3D). For reference, [IBM sold off their personal computer division to China in 2005](http://www.nbcnews.com/id/7695811/ns/business-world_business/t/chinas-lenovo-acquires-ibm-division/), and a google search for "IBM smartphone" brings up a device made in 1994.

I'm ready to get in on Apple if they come back down again. I traded the stock and made some money off of them but I never went into long term hold. I want to buy more Microsoft of course. And I want to get into IBM because I like the new CEO plus a great dividend yield. mainly the new CEO tho. 

Food wise I'm wanting to get into SBUX after hearing their CEO talk about how many stores they are planning on opening in China and how they are doing there. 

I got a long list of 5g stocks I want to get in on too.

author: Kwc0055
body:
Dividend stocks: coke, IBM, AT&T etc. large mature companies that pay steady and reliable dividends. 

Growth stocks: Tesla, Nvidia, AMD, FB, Google etc etc. companies with rapid growth business models. Although fb and google seem to be slowing down lately they are still incredibly profitable.

author: nikolatosic
body:
Google is search based on text and hoping websites adjust to that using SEO soft influence. Their banners are more and more lowering quality of search and overall search use is dropping due to apps and closed websites. They are big but a niche. Their model works for specific products only.

Facebook is a developing world family and friendship automation. A lot of room to grow in places like Bangladesh. But technology which delivers value to customers is actually simple and they can easily be replaced. They are based on soft value not tech. 

Amazon us big in USA. It is a big country which used mail order catalogs way before internet. You can not have a store everywhere in America. Rest of the world isn't like that. They have been adding value to their offering because they want to offer the most for least like all retail but eventually someone will take this over. Just that their competitor can not be in USA or Europe. Europe is too small.

Data means nothing to customers. Customers want value for money. Data maybe can help speed up selection within millions of products but this doesn't really work as good as they promise. Ads and e-commerce recommendations are very much off once shoppers are not super easy predictable. Data and AI are a hype.

Microsoft also is a business software company with some diversification. In business it succeeds just like SAP and Oracle etc. It enters and it is hard to get it out. Not many players there as well as CIOs don't take much risk. But it's success is not because of them but simply because of digitalisation and globalisation. Microsoft itself hasn't created any relevant competitive value. They are just a big political entity in the right time and place. If something changes for them it will also change for SAP Oracle IBM etc. But they appear to be different because of hardware and games (more consumer) and Bill Gates always spent a lot on his PR.

author: paq12x
body:
Warren Buffett is a conservative investor.  His criteria are to maintain wealth for his clients.

Even that, in the last 20 years, he has been underperforming the market.  That's the period airline stocks were doing great (and he had a bunch of them).

He also sold IBM when at the end of 2019 when the stock hit its low.  Since then it recovered just to get hit again with COVID-19.  Currently, it's at the same level back in 2019.

This time,  I am betting that he's wrong.   I don't think the Fed would let a market segment that frequency talked about to go under.   The Fed and Trump won't let their $$$ that went into the airliners bailout package vaporize.  

The Fed will see their initial loan repaid even at the cost of dumping billion more in grant into the airliners. - Whatever it costs - is the stand the Fed is holding right now.   I will not bet against the Fed even if that means disagreeing with Warren.

author: zugiheos
body:
Just dig through archived forums to find what people thought of the giants of the past.


Every decade the top companies are almost all replaced by new ones (*) and noone ever sees it coming. It’s 1980s. IBM is king of the world. How could it ever loose value? It basically has a monopoly on PCs.


(Almost) All companies decline eventually and every time everyone thinks “this time is different”. The chances that the top 5 companies of this decade will be the 5 top ones of the next are nill. Some new trend will come, new industries will raise. Right now Google, FB are add platforms, apple is a hardware provider and Amazon is primarily a hosting service. There’s nothing glamorous, magical or irreplaceable about their business model. 


*: https://etfdb.com/history-of-the-s-and-p-500/

author: M4Herbs
body: True, IBM and Microsoft for example would have been a good pick too. But there is a long list of companies that either don’t exist no more, or are pretty much worthless in comparison. I think Forrest Gump did a good job overall.

author: adam250250
body: I think warren buffet has lost some of his edge. He missed out on all the good tech companies and instead opted for IBM. I see the tech industrys doing the best then insurance companies or healthcare companies coming in at second for sustainable growth.

author: tooeasilybored
body:
I felt the same way too then I’m reminded of the fact that a significant % of our population are nowhere near rational. 


Working at home is not new, its been done for a very long time. My dads been at IBM forever, and he’s been working at home since the 2000s. 

Companies know how much money they can save, it’s just that a lot of people would end up losing their job so that avenue was never pushed/explored too much as long as there was enough revenue coming in. Think of all those office mid level management types, most of those jobs would be eliminated. 

It’s also to show off, I worked for a company that had a contract with AC. They would bring these guys in, show them around the office, manufacturing facilities then head to the board room. 

So who knows, I’m thinking it’ll bounce back eventually as we get back to our old ways.

author: Nettletooth
body:
He sold out, so what.

Buffet has made plenty of mistakes in recent times.

KHC, we see how that is going? Might be choked out by debt eventually here. 
IBM, didn't ever do shit.
OXY, so how is that going? Now it is stuffed full of debt, a zombie in danger of bankruptcy. 

How did buying DAL on the dip work out? 

I have nothing bad to say about him as a person, but as an investor he is losing his touch somewhat. 

This is not to say I am bullish on airlines, but... I think Buffet is lost in this investing environment. This crisis has confused and bewildered many great investors, and some have adapted a lot better than others.

Plenty of funds are picking thier spots in the last month and raking in some great profits, but Buffet is there, stuck in the headlights.  He is not an oracle, merely a ordinary, reasonably good investor that don't hold a candle to Citadel, Renaissance, Two Sigma, Bridgewater, and many other funds.

author: patagoniacalling
body: Yikes! It seems Intel and IBM are competing with each other a lot these days to see who will race to bottom first.

author: MedEng3
body:
I'm not good at investing, despite my recent dumbass luck:

- +51% TSLA (01SEP20 to 02DEC20)

- +5% GLD (04DEC20 to 17JAN20)

- -17% IBM (03FEB20 to current)

Each year my wife and I compete against each other with an insignificant amount of money. She is up >50% since AUG20 in large due to AMD.

Is this sustainable? Of course not. All my real investments are in broad exposure indexes for the next 40-years. I can achieve average returns through diversification. I have no idea how to sustainably achieve above average returns.

author: Fujit0ra
body: I have FOMO going outside in NYC but can't risk getting this shit and spreading it to parents. Sigh, will stay inside. Long $AMZN, short $IBM

author: lost_in_life_34
body:
AMZN and MSFT are the ibm and other mainframe companies of the 70’s

The PC came along and killed mainframes. IOT and other small devices are the next PC

author: verbrand24
body:
This is pretty irrelevant, but I was on a project that took over a contract that IBM had. After seeing their code, business practices, and how horrifically things were ran I lost all confidence in IBM as a company.

This is irrelevant because the amount of people that were apart of that project was a super small fraction of the IBM employees, but I still have a bad taste in my mouth from dealing with that dumpster fire. 

Just being in the industry, I have no confidence in IBM's ability to challenge amazon, google, or Microsoft. They hire under qualified engineers to save a buck, they are horrible at developing talent, their pay isn't competitive, and frankly it's not as sexy working for IBM as it is google. Without the talent to tackle these challenging endeavors they'll never catch up. These tech titans are only big as their technical talent is.

As a disclaimer, I've never worked for IBM and these are just rumors, observations, and how their stock will relate to their product is a question mark from me.

author: worldnews_is_shit
body:
Ask any software engineer why would they choose IBM over Amazon for some project.

Stackoverflow's regularly votes IBM Watson and other cloud techs offered by IBM as one of the worst to work with.

IBM is prime example of the damaging effects bean counting can have on the culture and vision of a company. 

Why is the majority of IBM's workforce located in India? Why isn't the workforce more evenly distributed along other tech hubs like San Francisco, London, Berlin?

IBM is not focusing on the important things and that's why they are greatly underperforming in a sector that have had an unprecedented growth in the last decade.
